awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Novel development of a pediatric Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) scanner
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project focuses on the development of techniques that will facilitate the design and development of affordable, compact, and patient-friendly magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) systems. MRI systems are the preferred modality for a range of imaging types, notably pediatrics, due to their superior diagnostic capabilities, high resolution, and minimal side effects. However, traditional MRI experiences can be daunting for children due to the confined and noisy environment, often leading to alternatives such as the use of anesthesia for an MRI scan or the use of computerized tomography (CT), which exposes them to high levels of ionizing radiation. The objective of this project is to innovate novel techniques for developing a new generation of scanners, with a focus on creating child-friendly imaging experiences. These groundbreaking techniques have the potential to introduce new classes of MRI scanners, expand the imaging market, and democratize MRI systems to communities in need worldwide.

The intellectual merit of this project focuses on the development of B1 imaging approaches. While traditional MRI scanners rely on B0 gradient coils for spatial encoding, B1 coils have previously been shown to spatially encode, but they remain widely under-used and under-developed. The goal of this effort is to demonstrate the viability and expand upon the B1 imaging approach known as Frequency-modulated Rabi-Encoded Echoes (aka, FREE), specifically, frequency-encoded and phase-encoded FREE. FREE is unique from other B1 imaging approaches because of its high immunity to magnetic imperfections. FREE, unlike other approaches, can appropriately image in highly inhomogeneous (and inexpensive) magnets. A scanner built around FREE would take advantage of the cost savings that come with removing B0 gradient coils and from reducing the homogeneity of a magnet. An MRI scanner utilizing FREE would be more affordable, compact, and silent. This project will focus on demonstrating two- and three-dimensional imaging on a compact, affordable, and inhomogeneous 0.5 Tesla system, thereby demonstrating the capability of B1 imaging approaches.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Background: Fifty years ago, scientists investigated both B0 and B1 encoding. B0 encoding groups proposed using dedicated B0 gradient coil sets to spatially vary the Larmor (or precessional) frequency (w0=gB0, where g is the gyromagnetic ratio). B1 encoding groups proposed using B1 gradients to spatially vary the Rabi (or nutational) frequency (w1=gB1). In both approaches, scientists designed pulse sequences to traverse k-space and spatially-encode with their respective field gradients. Rotating Frame Zeugmatography first demonstrated B1 encoding, but several other approaches arose. B1 encoding presented several benefits over B0 encoding: 1) B1 field gradients encode silently, 2) B1-powered systems have more bore space for patients, 3) B1 coils are less expensive to manufacture,  and 4) a B1-encoded system could remove all B0 gradient coils and their associated costs. In their infancy, both approaches faced challenges. Eddy currents limited B0 gradients, and off-resonance effects limited B1 gradients. In 1986, a new type of gradient coils (shielded gradient coils) mitigated eddy currents and made B0 encoding the first viable path to modern MRI. B0 encoding became the industry standard, and despite B1 encoding’s potential to make smaller, cheaper, and quieter scanners, it was largely left behind.

Adialante revisits B1 encoding to develop a new type of MRI architecture that can reach the nearly 90% of the world that lack access. Our exclusive B1 encoding approach, Frequency-modulated Rabi Encoded Echoes (FREE), enables B1 encoding to image as effectively as B0 encoding, while simultaneously being resistant to severe off-resonance. Like active-gradient coils solving the eddy current problem, FREE solves the off-resonant sensitivity that plagued early B1 approaches. Adialante, using Frequency-modulated Rabi Encoded Echoes (FREE), can bring B1 encoding to fruition and revolutionize the imaging industry with MRI scanners that are cheaper, quieter, and smaller than any equivalent B0 encoded system.

Conclusions: During this NSF SBIR Phase I, Adialante validated our novel B1 encoding approaches by demonstrating experimental 2D B1 imaging and creating a library of B1-encoded pulse sequences. We imaged a small phantom with Adialante's logo (ADIA) showing sub-0.2mm resolution, showed our proprietary model-based reconstructions correcting geometric distortions, and designed Adia-Brain by interviewing over 140 clinical stakeholders to better inform our design. Adia-Brain, our flagship product, is a mid-field head-only MRI scanner that will be silent and 1/10th the cost and size of traditional MRI scanners. Compared to other portable, low-cost systems, our B1 encoding and field strength will enable an image quality 5x-7x better than competitors. Phase I results enabled us to validate our imaging to completely design Adia-Brain. Adia-Brain, because of B1 encoding, will solve the delays in diagnosis that stroke and pediatric patients face every day, a problem an accessible MRI system could readily solve. The Phase I results lay the groundwork for Adia-Brain to be completed and support the advancement of this project to a Phase II.
